Grazie Wozz (- l'atra meta e inglese e abito a Londra). 
Wozz points out that that this image is in the same genre as the comic carictures of Neapolitan entertainers like Toto and Peppino and that as such they aren't a faithful representation of real life. I agree but it's one thing for an Italian audience to consume such images and quite another for them to be presented in a US publication for a non-Italian audience which would not have been able to make such a nuanced reading as Wozz proposes.My point is that we are more likely to have a positive view of foreigners if  ourperception of them is not based on comic caricatures. These days we're floooded with images of people from all over the world but when this image was disseminated it may well have been the only picture many people had seen of Italians.

comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/alandenney/] You're looking at an image from the late 19th century, when it was still absolutely common to attach human zoos to World's Fairs to show the visitors how "primitive tribes" behaved in their habitat, including the 1893 Columbian Exposition in Chicago with its famed Midway Plaisance. Also, the print originates in Switzerland  – Photoglob Zürich, the original publisher, routinely purchased black & white photos  from local photographers in bulk to turn into color photochroms, so chances are this is is how a Neapolitan photographer saw his hometown. The Detroit Publishing Co. was simply the North American licensee. PZ captioned most of its prints in the local language to add some local flair, but as you can see from the many comments in this set, they often enough got it wrong...

comment._content: Joining the conversation a few years later, I found an entry in the scholarly Encyclopedia of Pasta by Oretta Zanini De Vita, which says that poor workers eating pasta with cheese by hand was a common sight in Naples during and after the 18th century, when pasta was finally cheap enough for the poor to eat. According to de Vita: "Grand Tour travelers to Naples watched with amusement the daily meal of the so-called lazzari, at the street corners, who with a deft movement of the fingers, slid maccheroni dressed with cheese into their mouths." The maccheroni in use was not the macaroni of America, but was similar to bucatini, long, straight, and with a hole in the middle. books.google.com/books?id=D5nXAbSifIgC&lpg=PA6&ot... LOC: One improvement that can be made in your online presentation of the Photochroms is to include the caption on the print itself in your Notes. Instead, it looks like you have in all cases used an identification that comes from the American publisher's catalog. In some cases, like this one, the English translation is wrong and/or misleading. Trialanderrors, above, touches on this too. Also, researchers who have the print and want to use the caption to search online cannot reach it in your collection. I think you should add the captions, though I'm sure that is not a simple project.
